name: 1607_A. Linear Keyboard
description:
You are given a keyboard that consists of 26 keys. The keys are arranged sequentially in one row in a certain order. Each key corresponds to a unique lowercase Latin letter.

You have to type the word s on this keyboard. It also consists only of lowercase Latin letters.

To type a word, you need to type all its letters consecutively one by one. To type each letter you must position your hand exactly over the corresponding key and press it.

Moving the hand between the keys takes time which is equal to the absolute value of the difference between positions of these keys (the keys are numbered from left to right). No time is spent on pressing the keys and on placing your hand over the first letter of the word.

For example, consider a keyboard where the letters from 'a' to 'z' are arranged in consecutive alphabetical order. The letters 'h', 'e', 'l' and 'o' then are on the positions 8, 5, 12 and 15, respectively. Therefore, it will take |5 - 8| + |12 - 5| + |12 - 12| + |15 - 12| = 13 units of time to type the word "hello". 

Determine how long it will take to print the word s.

Input

The first line contains an integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 1000) — the number of test cases.

The next 2t lines contain descriptions of the test cases.

The first line of a description contains a keyboard — a string of length 26, which consists only of lowercase Latin letters. Each of the letters from 'a' to 'z' appears exactly once on the keyboard.

The second line of the description contains the word s. The word has a length from 1 to 50 letters inclusive and consists of lowercase Latin letters.

Output

Print t lines, each line containing the answer to the corresponding test case. The answer to the test case is the minimal time it takes to type the word s on the given keyboard.

Example

Input


5
abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz
hello
abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz
i
abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz
codeforces
qwertyuiopasdfghjklzxcvbnm
qqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqq
qwertyuiopasdfghjklzxcvbnm
abacaba


Output


13
0
68
0
74

prompt:
You've received a keyboard comprising 26 keys. These keys are organized sequentially in one line based on a particular sequence. Each key corresponds to a unique lowercase Latin letter.

You have to type the word s on this keyboard. It also consists only of lowercase Latin letters.

To input a word, you need to type all its letters consecutively, one after the other. To type each letter, you must align your hand precisely over the corresponding key and then press it.

Shifting your hand between the keys consumes time, equivalent to the absolute difference between the positions of these keys (the keys are numbered from left to right). No time is wasted pressing the keys or positioning your hand over the first letter of the word.

For example, consider a keyboard where the letters from 'a' to 'z' are arranged in consecutive alphabetical order. The letters 'h', 'e', 'l', and 'o' then are on the positions 8, 5, 12 and 15, respectively. Consequently, it will take |5 - 8| + |12 - 5| + |12 - 12| + |15 - 12| = 13 units of time to type the word "hello". 

Calculate how long it will take to print the word s. Consider optimizing hand movements to minimize time overall. Pay attention to the keyboard layout to derive the correct sequence of positions for calculating time efficiently.

Input

The first line contains an integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 1000) — the number of test cases.

The next 2t lines contain descriptions of the test cases.

The first line of a description contains a keyboard — a string of length 26, which consists only of lowercase Latin letters. Each of the letters from 'a' to 'z' appears exactly once on the keyboard.

The second line of the description contains the word s. The word has a length from 1 to 50 letters inclusive and consists of lowercase Latin letters.

Output

Print t lines, each line containing the answer to the corresponding test case. The answer to the test case is the minimal time it takes to type the word s on the given keyboard.

Example

Input


5
abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz
hello
abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz
i
abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz
codeforces
qwertyuiopasdfghjklzxcvbnm
qqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqq
qwertyuiopasdfghjklzxcvbnm
abacaba


Output


13
0
68
0
74

You've received a keyboard comprising 26 keys. These keys are organized sequentially in one line based on a particular sequence. Each key corresponds to a unique lowercase Latin letter.

You have to type the word s on this keyboard. It also consists only of lowercase Latin letters.

To input a word, you need to type all its letters consecutively, one after the other. To type each letter, you must align your hand precisely over the corresponding key and then press it.

Shifting your hand between the keys consumes time, equivalent to the absolute difference between the positions of these keys (the keys are numbered from left to right). No time is wasted pressing the keys or positioning your hand over the first letter of the word.

For example, consider a keyboard where the letters from 'a' to 'z' are arranged in consecutive alphabetical order. The letters 'h', 'e', 'l', and 'o' then are on the positions 8, 5, 12 and 15, respectively. Consequently, it will take |5 - 8| + |12 - 5| + |12 - 12| + |15 - 12| = 13 units of time to type the word "hello". 

Calculate how long it will take to print the word s. Consider optimizing hand movements to minimize time overall. Pay attention to the keyboard layout to derive the correct sequence of positions for calculating time efficiently.

Input

The first line contains an integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 1000) — the number of test cases.

The next 2t lines contain descriptions of the test cases.

The first line of a description contains a keyboard — a string of length 26, which consists only of lowercase Latin letters. Each of the letters from 'a' to 'z' appears exactly once on the keyboard.

The second line of the description contains the word s. The word has a length from 1 to 50 letters inclusive and consists of lowercase Latin letters.

Output

Print t lines, each line containing the answer to the corresponding test case. The answer to the test case is the minimal time it takes to type the word s on the given keyboard.

-------
Important Note: You must follow the input output format. Input must be taken from standard input and output must be given to standard output. The code will be tested against multiple test cases and all the test cases must be passed.

Write a main() function and use input() function to read input from stdin

from typing import List
## main.py

def calculate_typing_time(keyboard: str, word: str) -> int:
    """
    Calculate the time required to type a given word on a specific keyboard layout.
    
    Args:
        keyboard (str): A string of length 26 representing the keyboard layout.
        word (str): The word to be typed.
        
    Returns:
        int: The total time required to type the word.
    """
    # Create a dictionary to map each letter to its position on the keyboard
    keyboard_positions = {}
    for index, letter in enumerate(keyboard):
        keyboard_positions[letter] = index
    
    # Initialize the total time to 0
    total_time = 0
    
    # Calculate the time for the first letter (no movement cost)
    previous_position = keyboard_positions[word[0]]
    
    # Calculate the time for the rest of the letters
    for letter in word[1:]:
        current_position = keyboard_positions[letter]
        total_time += abs(current_position - previous_position)
        previous_position = current_position
    
    return total_time

# Read input from the user
keyboard = input()
word = input()

# Calculate and print the result
result = calculate_typing_time(keyboard, word)
print(result)
from typing import List
## main.py

def calculate_typing_time(keyboard: str, word: str) -> int:
    # Create a dictionary to map each letter to its position on the keyboard
    keyboard_positions = {}
    for index, letter in enumerate(keyboard):
        keyboard_positions[letter] = index
    
    # Initialize the total time to 0
    total_time = 0
    
    # Initialize the position of the previous letter to the position of the first letter in the word
    prev_position = keyboard_positions[word[0]]
    
    # Calculate the time for each letter in the word
    for letter in word:
        current_position = keyboard_positions[letter]
        total_time += abs(current_position - prev_position)
        prev_position = current_position
    
    return total_time

# Read the number of test cases from standard input
import sys

if len(sys.argv) != 1:
    print("Usage: python main.py")
    sys.exit(1)

t = int(input().strip())

# Process each test case
for _ in range(t):
    # Read the keyboard layout
    keyboard = input().strip()
    # Read the word to be typed
    word = input().strip()
    # Calculate and print the typing time for the word
    result = calculate_typing_time(keyboard, word)
    print(result)
from typing import List
## main.py

def calculate_typing_time(keyboard: str, word: str) -> int:
    # Create a dictionary to map each key to its position on the keyboard
    key_positions = {}
    for index, key in enumerate(keyboard):
        key_positions[key] = index
    
    # Initialize the typing time
    typing_time = 0
    
    # Calculate the typing time for the word
    for i in range(1, len(word)):
        current_key = word[i]
        previous_key = word[i - 1]
        typing_time += abs(key_positions[current_key] - key_positions[previous_key])
    
    return typing_time

# Read the number of test cases
t = int(input())

# Process each test case
for _ in range(t):
    keyboard = input()
    word = input()
    result = calculate_typing_time(keyboard, word)
    print(result)
from typing import List
## main.py

def calculate_typing_time(keyboard: str, word: str) -> int:
    """
    Calculate the time required to type a given word on a specific keyboard layout.
    
    Args:
        keyboard (str): A string of length 26 representing the keyboard layout.
        word (str): The word to be typed.
        
    Returns:
        int: The total time required to type the word.
    """
    # Create a dictionary to map each letter to its position on the keyboard
    keyboard_positions = {}
    for index, letter in enumerate(keyboard):
        keyboard_positions[letter] = index
    
    # Initialize the total time to 0
    total_time = 0
    
    # Calculate the time to type the word
    for i in range(1, len(word)):
        current_position = keyboard_positions[word[i]]
        previous_position = keyboard_positions[word[i - 1]]
        total_time += abs(current_position - previous_position)
    
    return total_time

# Read input from stdin
import sys

# Read the number of test cases
t = int(sys.stdin.readline().strip())

# Process each test case
for _ in range(t):
    # Read the keyboard layout
    keyboard = sys.stdin.readline().strip()
    # Read the word to be typed
    word = sys.stdin.readline().strip()
    # Calculate and print the typing time for the word
    result = calculate_typing_time(keyboard, word)
    print(result)

## main.py

def calculate_typing_time(keyboard: str, word: str) -> int:
    # Create a dictionary to map each character to its position on the keyboard
    keyboard_positions = {}
    for index, char in enumerate(keyboard):
        keyboard_positions[char] = index
    
    # Initialize the total time to 0
    total_time = 0
    
    # Calculate the time to type the word
    for i in range(1, len(word)):
        current_pos = keyboard_positions[word[i]]
        previous_pos = keyboard_positions[word[i - 1]]
        total_time += abs(current_pos - previous_pos)
    
    return total_time

# Read the number of test cases
t = int(input())

# Process each test case
for _ in range(t):
    keyboard = input()
    word = input()
    result = calculate_typing_time(keyboard, word)
    print(result)
from typing import List
## main.py

import sys

def calculate_typing_time(keyboard: str, word: str) -> int:
    # Create a dictionary to map each key to its position on the keyboard
    key_positions = {}
    for index, key in enumerate(keyboard):
        key_positions[key] = index
    
    # Initialize the total typing time
    total_time = 0
    
    # Calculate the typing time for each letter in the word
    for i in range(1, len(word)):
        current_key = word[i]
        previous_key = word[i - 1]
        # Add the absolute difference in positions to the total time
        total_time += abs(key_positions[current_key] - key_positions[previous_key])
    
    return total_time

# Read the number of test cases
t = int(input().strip())

# Process each test case
for _ in range(t):
    keyboard = input().strip()
    word = input().strip()
    result = calculate_typing_time(keyboard, word)
    print(result)
from typing import List
## main.py

def calculate_typing_time(keyboard: str, word: str) -> int:
    """
    Calculate the time required to type a given word on a specific keyboard layout.
    
    Args:
        keyboard (str): A string of length 26 representing the keyboard layout.
        word (str): The word to be typed.
        
    Returns:
        int: The total time required to type the word.
    """
    # Create a dictionary to map each letter to its position on the keyboard
    keyboard_positions = {char: index for index, char in enumerate(keyboard)}
    
    # Initialize the total time to 0
    total_time = 0
    
    # Calculate the time for each letter in the word
    for i in range(1, len(word)):
        current_pos = keyboard_positions[word[i]]
        previous_pos = keyboard_positions[word[i - 1]]
        total_time += abs(current_pos - previous_pos)
    
    return total_time

# Read input from stdin
keyboard = input()
word = input()
t = int(input())

# Process each test case
for _ in range(t):
    result = calculate_typing_time(keyboard, word)
    print(result)
from typing import List
## main.py

def calculate_typing_time(keyboard: str, word: str) -> int:
    # Create a dictionary to map each character to its position on the keyboard
    keyboard_positions = {}
    for index, char in enumerate(keyboard):
        keyboard_positions[char] = index
    
    # Initialize the total time to 0
    total_time = 0
    
    # Calculate the time to type the word
    for i in range(1, len(word)):
        # Get the positions of the current and previous characters
        current_pos = keyboard_positions[word[i]]
        previous_pos = keyboard_positions[word[i - 1]]
        
        # Calculate the time to move from the previous character to the current character
        time_to_move = abs(current_pos - previous_pos)
        
        # Add the time to the total time
        total_time += time_to_move
    
    return total_time

# Read the number of test cases
n = int(input())

# Process each test case
for _ in range(n):
    keyboard = input()
    word = input()
    result = calculate_typing_time(keyboard, word)
    print(result)
from typing import List
## main.py

def calculate_typing_time(keyboard: str, word: str) -> int:
    """
    Calculate the time required to type a word based on the positions of the keys on the keyboard.

    Args:
        keyboard (str): A string of length 26 representing the keyboard layout.
        word (str): The word to be typed.

    Returns:
        int: The total time required to type the word.
    """
    # Create a dictionary to map each key to its position on the keyboard
    key_positions = {}
    for index, key in enumerate(keyboard):
        key_positions[key] = index

    # Initialize the total typing time
    total_time = 0

    # Calculate the typing time for each letter in the word
    for i in range(len(word) - 1):
        current_key = word[i]
        next_key = word[i + 1]
        current_position = key_positions[current_key]
        next_position = key_positions[next_key]
        total_time += abs(current_position - next_position)

    return total_time

# Read input from the user
keyboard = input()
word = input()

# Calculate and print the result
result = calculate_typing_time(keyboard, word)
print(result)
from typing import List
## main.py

def calculate_typing_time(keyboard: str, word: str) -> int:
    """
    Calculate the time required to type a word based on the keyboard layout.

    Args:
        keyboard (str): A string of length 26 representing the keyboard layout.
        word (str): The word to be typed.

    Returns:
        int: The total time required to type the word.
    """
    # Create a dictionary to map each letter to its position on the keyboard
    keyboard_positions = {}
    for index, letter in enumerate(keyboard):
        keyboard_positions[letter] = index

    # Initialize the total time to 0
    total_time = 0

    # Calculate the time to type the word
    for i in range(1, len(word)):
        current_position = keyboard_positions[word[i]]
        previous_position = keyboard_positions[word[i - 1]]
        total_time += abs(current_position - previous_position)

    return total_time

# Read the number of test cases
n = int(input().strip())

# Process each test case
for _ in range(n):
    keyboard = input().strip()
    word = input().strip()
    result = calculate_typing_time(keyboard, word)
    print(result)

examples:
Input

The first line contains an integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 1000) — the number of test cases.

The next 2t lines contain descriptions of the test cases.

The first line of a description contains a keyboard — a string of length 26, which consists only of lowercase Latin letters. Each of the letters from 'a' to 'z' appears exactly once on the keyboard.

The second line of the description contains the word s. The word has a length from 1 to 50 letters inclusive and consists of lowercase Latin letters.

Output

Print t lines, each line containing the answer to the corresponding test case. The answer to the test case is the minimal time it takes to type the word s on the given keyboard.

Example

Input


5
abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz
hello
abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz
i
abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz
codeforces
qwertyuiopasdfghjklzxcvbnm
qqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqq
qwertyuiopasdfghjklzxcvbnm
abacaba


Output


13
0
68
0
74
